name: places/ChIJcRqSoc9ZwokRdqp5YiLZcBI
adrFormatAddress: 1865 Broadway, New York, NY 10023, USA

originalText.text:
Recently twisted my ankle on one of our many cracked city sidewalks. I had was planning to go to the emergency room, but my very intelligent daughter reminded me that I would spend the a very long time sitting there.

She convinced me to go online and look for a podiatrist; this I did. I found one that took my insurance (Medicare) and was accepting new patients. However, when we got to his office he informed us that he did not do ankles.

We thought he was joking, but he wasn’t; that’s a thing. He very helpfully, pointed us the the urgent care on West 56 (a plus, because it was literally around the corner from him and I was having a hard time putting any form of pressure on my right foot).

The urgent care office was great. They bound my ankle (by the way, the wait was very reasonable and the staff amazing) and gave me a referral to the orthopedic doctor at 61st Street.

Again, I was blown away by their professionalism and helpfulness. Previously, I had a very bad attitude about all of these popping up all over the city. It felt like a junk food franchise. And I thought they would not be as good as my doctor (whom I could no longer afford to see) or a “real” hospital, but I was very, very wrong and I’m extremely happy to have been proven so.

originalText.text: I've experienced quality care from my general practitioner, the other doctors I've seen so far all the other staff I've interacted with. The wait times are short, the doctors are not rushed are  and I've received detailed messages covering all aspects of my visit as follow-up. I am recommending this service to others.

The wait times are short, the doctors are not rushed are  and I've received detailed messages covering all aspects of my visit as follow-up. I am recommending this service to others.

originalText.text: This review is not for Summit Health overall. It is in response to the dismissive Dr. Demesh. I tried to get CT scan results for nearly a year. When I finally got a response & went in to receive them I also needed to address a nasal lesion & infected throat. I had to go into Urgent Care twice for this issue & Demesh acted like it was a non-issue. He didn't even take a throat culture to narrow down what the issue could be. I agree with other people on this thread that he doesn't listen to Black folks or POC, in general.

text.text: This review is not for Summit Health overall. It is in response to the dismissive Dr. Demesh. I tried to get CT scan results for nearly a year. When I finally got a response & went in to receive them I also needed to address a nasal lesion & infected throat. I had to go into Urgent Care twice for this issue & Demesh acted like it was a non-issue. He didn't even take a throat culture to narrow down what the issue could be. I agree with other people on this thread that he doesn't listen to Black folks or POC, in general.

originalText.text:
There's an echo in here... AVOID the fraudster DR. DEMESH. He will most likely perform a nasal endoscopy on you without warning and without consent and bill you $800 for it, and insurance won't cover it if you have a deductible. It's also considered "surgery" - so even if you paid your deductible, you probably still have a surgery deductible to pay. It's fraud. He is performing 5-second endoscopies that do not even approach the standard of care outlined by the AMA or Medicare for this procedure and billing $$$ for it. I was also billed 45+ min for my first appointment that was 10-15 min and for a "long" appointment for my second appointment, which was definitely 10 min or less.

Aside from that, Dr. Demesh was entire dismissive of my claims of vertigo and only begrudgingly sent me for the tests with the audiologist. He didnt think the problem was in my ears at all. He kept trying to blame it on a drop in blood pressure when i stand up, even tho I explained the problem was when I TURN MY HEAD and sit up from bed. (Textbook BPPV.)

The front desk told me there was no copay for the audiologist and then I got a $200+ bill. They scheduled me 2 weeks out for the next available test. Then called the day before that day and said there were not test that day, she was only in the office one day a week. I had to wait almost another 2 weeks for my testing day.

During the tests I vommited twice. So much for no problem with my ears. When I went to get the test results. He scoped ME AGAIN and wasn't willing to discuss the results in depth. Just told me to grab a PT referral on my way out.

The office is always way behind and you'll wait a long time. The front desk is always having a party and will straight up ignore you standing there waiting for your PT referral while they finish their chit-chat.

Why did I even go back to this Dr? I was in so much distress and had invested so much time already and it was so hard to get another appointment elsewhere.

If you have vertigo GO STRAIGHT TO THE PHYSICAL THERAPIST; you don't need a referral. And then work out the cause with an ENT. A PT can evaluate you for BPPV. My PT (at Spear UWS)  is an order of magnitude better than Dr. Demesh. I only wish I would have know I could go there w/o a Dr referral.

originalText.text: I’ve been to Summit over the past several years for three unrelated gym injuries, first referred by CityMD.  The facilities are clean and modern, no long waits, friendly check in people.   Dr. Hussain, the main orthopedist, was extremely knowledgeable, friendly, gave me a lot of useful information.   When necessary, he provided referrals to PT, and one injury required surgery, for which he sent me to one of the best NYC surgeons.   I heartily recommend Summit.
